registry_keys_set: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Cryptography\Defaults\Provider\Microsoft Enhanced RSA and AES Cryptographic Provider

mitre_attack_techniques.signature_description: Adversaries may attempt to hide artifacts associated with their behaviors to evade detection.
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate features of their artifacts to make them appear legitimate or benign to users and/or security tools.

Adversaries may interact with the Windows Registry to hide configuration information within Registry keys, remove information as part of cleaning up, or as part of other techniques to aid in persistence and execution.
Adversaries may circumvent mechanisms designed to control elevate privileges to gain higher-level permissions.
Adversaries may set files and directories to be hidden to evade detection mechanisms.
Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic.
Adversaries may abuse task scheduling functionality to facilitate initial or recurring execution of malicious code.
Adversaries may attempt to get information about running processes on a system.
Creates job files (autostart)
Tries to load missing DLLs
Writes to foreign memory regions
May try to detect the Windows Explorer process (often used for injection)
Changes memory attributes in foreign processes to executable or writable
Creates a thread in another existing process (thread injection)
Allocates memory in foreign processes
Creates files inside the user directory
Creates files inside the system directory
Creates guard pages, often used to prevent reverse engineering and debugging
Contains medium sleeps (>= 30s)
May sleep (evasive loops) to hinder dynamic analysis
Contains long sleeps (>= 3 min)
Allocates memory with a write watch (potentially for evading sandboxes)
Binary may include packed or crypted data
Binary may include packed or crypted data
PE file has an executable .text section which is very likely to contain packed code (zlib compression ratio < 0.3)
Creates a DirectInput object (often for capturing keystrokes)
May try to detect the virtual machine to hinder analysis (VM artifact strings found in memory)
May try to detect the Windows Explorer process (often used for injection)
Queries a list of all running processes
Sample monitors Window changes (e.g. starting applications), analyze the sample with the simulation cookbook
Queries the cryptographic machine GUID
Reads software policies
Queries the volume information (name, serial number etc) of a device
Uses HTTPS
Uses HTTPS for network communication, use the SSL MITM Proxy cookbook for further analysis
Uses HTTPS
